title: 107_s2723
content: The "Transitional Housing Assistance for Victims of Domestic Violence Act of 2002" authorizes grants for organizations to provide housing assistance to individuals fleeing domestic violence situations where emergency shelter services are insufficient. Grants under this Act can be used for short-term housing assistance and support services for individuals fleeing domestic violence situations. SEC. 4 of the Act states that assistance shall be provided for up to 18 months, with a waiver option for an additional 6 months for individuals unable to acquire permanent housing despite good-faith efforts. Each eligible entity seeking a grant under this Act must submit an application to the Attorney General with necessary information. The application should describe the activities for which assistance is needed and provide assurances for compliance. Victims are not required to participate in the criminal justice system to receive services, and domestic violence advocates must maintain client confidentiality. The Act also includes provisions for reporting. Each recipient of a grant under this Act must annually report to the Attorney General on the individuals and dependents assisted, types of housing assistance provided, amount of assistance given, duration of assistance received, and reasons for assistance. The Attorney General must annually report to Congress on the individuals and dependents assisted under the Act, including those not provided assistance due to lack of housing availability, and the types of support services provided. The Attorney General must annually report to Congress on individuals and dependents assisted under the Act, including those not provided assistance due to lack of housing availability and types of support services. The report will be transmitted to the Office of Community Planning and Development at the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, and the Office of Women's Health at the United States Department of Health and Human Services. Authorization of appropriations. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $30,000,000 annually from 2003 to 2006. Limitations state that only 3 percent can be used for salaries and administrative expenses. States must receive a minimum of .75 percent of the total grant amount unless all eligible applications are funded. In the fiscal year, the United States Virgin Islands, American Samoa, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands each receive .25 percent of the total grant amount allocated under this Act.
